summary:
=== Purchase Information ===
Review Date: 2014/09/28
Average Rating: 3.6
Product Details: {'Subtitles': ['None available'], 'Directors': ['Stuart Hackshaw'], 'Producers': ['Rajiv Whabi', 'Paul Mills'], 'Starring': ['Alex Childs', 'Richard Brimblecomb', 'Judith Eveson'], 'Studio': ['Oakwood Films']}
Review Text: They sort of followed the general plot of the short story. However, they failed to describe how the main character was being repressed by her husband. That was a HUGE component in the text. Wasn't the room supposed to be converted from an old nursery? I didn't get that feeling. And, they certainly didn't build the connection between her increased writing and the emergence of her apparent illness. Just because the text is short does not mean the movie should have less. It certainly felt that way. Who ever converted the text for screen definitely should have stood their ground on keeping true to the meaning of the text. Maybe a student indie film will pick up the text and do it some justice.
Review Title: Kind of a let down if you've read the story already.
Rating: 2.0
--------------------------------------------------

Review Text: The players and the plots are top notch. There's not one dull moment or scene without a purpose and things just seem to unravel.
Review Title: One of the best series I have ever seen.
Rating: 5.0
--------------------------------------------------
=== Purchase Information ===
Review Date: 2014/11/24
Average Rating: 3.7
Product Details: {'Content advisory': ['Violence', 'frightening scenes', 'sexual content'], 'Audio languages': ['English'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['Christian James'], 'Producers': ['Richard Kerrigan (Producer)', 'Daniel Pickering (Exec Prod)'], 'Starring': ['Dan Palmer', 'Tamaryn Payne', 'Antonia Bernath'], 'Studio': ["Uncork'd Entertainment"]}
Review Text: I get that this is not the more common heavily animated film. And for that, I'm thankful. The story was fun! There were moments where characters were innovatively extended by use of inanimate objects. The characters were kept to a minimum which was nice. There weren't many uneven moments where I thought, "why is this person even here?" Also, the whole thing was funny. If you're someone with a short attention span who needs something like Yo-Gabba-Gabba or the Transformers series to justify a decent film, this will be disappointing. On the other end of the stick, this movie isn't some intellectual nose-picker. That said, the film is just fun!
Review Title: The film is just fun!
Rating: 5.0
--------------------------------------------------
=== Purchase Information ===
Review Date: 2015/09/05
Average Rating: 4.1
Product Details: {'Content advisory': ['Violence', 'frightening scenes', 'smoking', 'foul language'], 'Audio languages': ['English', 'English [Audio Description]'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['Sergio Mimica-Gezzan'], 'Producers': ['Aidan Elliott', 'Mark Huffam'], 'Starring': ['Mike Coulter', 'Sarah Armstrong', 'Steven Waddington'], 'Studio': ['Shout! Factory']}
Review Text: All I can say is that I was not concerned about who may live or die in this film. They made two character out to have some hidden rivalry and never did anything with it. These guys had almost two hours and wasted it. This movie is a great example of how to take an interesting plot and ruin it. I actually want my money back.
Review Title: How to take an interesting plot and ruin it:
Rating: 1.0
--------------------------------------------------

Review Text: well this was just a beginners project? The script dialog was inconsistent with the setting and characters. That actors made strange and irrelevant choices. The director made even stranger choices. Not sure why they shot the calmer moments at 60fps if this is supposed to have 1970s vibe to it. I think I could only handle 10 minutes before giving up.

Review Text: Donnie Yen barely shows any emotion. The film goes nowhere, and it's half the story line that caries most crappy martial arts films, which is some foreigner or idiot trying to screw over China. I spent the last hour trying to figure out what the hell I just watched.

    SUMMARY:
    [Final synthesis of preferences and patterns]
raw_response:
SUMMARY:
The individual exhibits distinct patterns in their ratings and sentiments, often oscillating between high appreciation and strong dissatisfaction. A noticeable preference for character-driven narratives and engaging plots emerges, particularly reflected in higher ratings for well-structured content. Conversely, their ratings drop significantly for films perceived as lacking depth or coherence, highlighting an aversion to poorly executed storylines.

Common themes include a taste for drama and character exploration, but the individual values successful adaptations of written works, as evidenced by their frustration when key story elements are misrepresented. They are drawn to concise, meaningful narratives over convoluted plots or excessive filler, suggesting a preference for quality over quantity.

In terms of quality and price sensitivity, the reviewer demonstrates a higher tolerance for mid-range pricing when satisfied with product quality, but exhibits strong disappointment at perceived value loss, leading to lower ratings for movies that do not meet expectations. The preference leans towards compelling storytelling and character growth, with less emphasis on visual spectacle if the narrative fails to resonate.

Overall, the core preferences indicate a discerning viewer who enjoys thoughtful storytelling and character depth, yet shows a low tolerance for narratives that lack clarity or that misrepresent the essence of the source material.

target_interaction.title: transformers movie but in horror genre
target_interaction.text: beautiful shots, excellent grading and lighting... cheap jump scares... don't really care what happens to any of the characters because the storytelling is lacking in that department. It's an okay thing to have playing in the background during parties
